bibl.title: Letter from W. F. Draper to Henry Rose Carter, December 18, 1917

div1.p: Draper informs Carter of the anti-malarial work done around Camp Lee.

div1.head: Letter from W. F. Draper to Henry Rose Carter, December 18, 1917
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
m. c
(See)
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Petersburg, Va., Dec. 18, 1917.
Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
U. S. Marine Hospital,
Baltimore, Md.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
In reply to your letter of December 11, 1917, I have
the following information to give:

After your survey had been completed, it was impossible
to secure funds for carrying on anti-malarial work around the
Camp in time for the Service to accomplish anything along this
line. Major Henry P. Carter had a force of between seven hundred
and eight hundred men at work clearing, draining, and ditching
the camp area itself, and, knowing that we would be unable to
get started for a time, he did not stop strictly at the camp
limits but went beyond. He took care of all of the places which
you had marked in the immediate vicinity of the camp on the
outside. He also cared for the oiling along the concrete road
almost to the Petersburg end.

There was no work at all done around the old mill in
Ettricks nor in Colonial Heights. In Petersburg, the Health
Officer made an attempt at carrying out your suggestions and
directions but considerable was left undone. I had so much to
do in connection with raising money, organizing a force, and get-
#2
ting things started, that I was not able to keep after the
Health Officer all the time.

There was very little malaria among the workmen at the
Camp. YouWe never heard of more than five or six cases. In the
City of Petersburg, twelve positive smears were diagnosed at the
laboratory out of about forty sent in. As you know, the doctors
and citizens of Petersburg are of the opinion that malaria does
not prevail to any great extent in this vicinity.

I am in receipt of a letter from the Bureau dated
October 29, 1917 instructing me to furnish a statement in regard
to the present status of the studies of this disease and its
eradication in this district, and also an estimate as to the
total cost of the work which remains to be done. I immediately
get in touch with Major Carter, who was the only officer in this
region who could assist me in obtaining this information, and
he and I spent two half days in going over the situation. The
notes which we made are enclosed herewith. Major Carter and I
had arranged to spend an entire day in the field collectionng addi-
tional data, but before this could be done, he was suddenly ordered
to Houston, Texas and departed immediately. There is no one
around here now who knows anything about anti-malarial measures
and it will be exceedingly difficult for me to furnish information
which the Bureau desired, as I myself have had absolutely no
experience in this line of work.

I hope that this will serve to asnwer some of your
questions and that you will let me know if there is anything
further which I can give.
div1.closer: Sincerely, W.F. Draper P. A. SURGEON.
